title: Robert Louis Stevenson
author: Black, Margaret Moyes
snippet: The Rev. Dr Lewis Balfour of Colinton was the third son of Mr Balfour,the Laird of Pilrig. The quaint old house of Pilrig stands a little backfrom Leith Walk, the date on it is 1638; and the text inscribed on itsdoor-stone, 'For we know, that if our earthly house of this tabernaclewere dissolved we have a building of God, an house not made with handseternal in the heavens,' is a fitting motto for a race whose firstprominent ancestor was that James Balfour of Reformation times, who notonly was a cousin of Melville the Reformer, but who married one of theMelville family. This double tie to those so entwined with the very lifeof that great period in Scotland's history brought Mr James Balfour intovery close communion with such men as Erskine of Dun, the Rev. JohnDurie, and many others of the Reforming ministers and gentlemen, withwhom a member of the Pilrig family, the late James Balfour-Melville,Esq., W.S., in his interesting pamphlet dealing with his family says,that his ancestor had much godly conversation and communing.

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: ' " Bide a wee, an' hear me oot! Here's Mrs. Muir ismy freen, an' she's your freen tae, an' richt weel she kensBaillie Peter Arnold o' the Leith Walk ! He may be auld,an' a widower, an' he may be stiff-neckit, an' a' that, buthe's no the man to betray twa bonnie, winsome een ! Hisword is as guid as his bond ony day. An' noo, Miss Polly,ye maun tell us yer faither's an' yer mither's address, an' layyer wee hand here; an' promise ye'll no say ' nae' to anauld man that would mak' ye mistress o' his gowd an' siller,an' a braw big hoose in Leith Walk."

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: Uncle Peter Arnold's ' hoose in the Leith Walk' wasgetting what the housekeeper termed, ' a braw riggin' oot,'for ' Maister Joe Hanley was expectit hame the nicht, andno his lane, but wi' his sister, Miss Ivy,' whom the housekeeper had never seen, and whom she represented to herself as a very important personage indeed, with formidablefemale pretensions to grandeur and fashion.

title: Robert Louis Stevenson
author: Black, Margaret Moyes
snippet: In this book also are 'A Pastoral,' in which we learn to know John Todd,that typical shepherd of the Pentlands, and his dogs; the charming paperon 'The Character of Dogs,' and four literary essays beginning with anaccount of his early purchases in the old book shop in Leith Walk, andending in 'A Humble Remonstrance,' with a summary of his views onromance writing, and what it really ought to be.

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: " Mak' yer bundle an' gang awa' without delay. An' dinnaforget that ye've scrapit yer ain name oot o' my wull!"' After that you may be sure I had not the faintest inclination to remain on at Leith Walk. I went straight to GeordieStewart's lodgings, to unburden my heart to my old chum,and open a valve for my pent-up indignation.

title: Robert Louis Stevenson
author: Black, Margaret Moyes
snippet: Existence at Swanston was even more provocative of truant-playing thanit had been in Edinburgh, and Louis, in his later school days and hisearly sessions at the University, was more than ever conspicuous by hisabsence from classes, more lovingly wedded to long hours among thehills, long rambles about the 'Old Town,' the Figgate Whins, the port ofLeith, and the rapidly changing localities round Leith Walk, somewhatback from which, Pilrig, the ancient home of his ancestors, still standsgravely retired from the work-a-day world.

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: AuntAlison, in her Sunday gown, arrives on my arm, to performthe honours at the tea-tray. She is quite at home atLeith Walk, and says " uncle dear " to the host, and looksafter the furniture, and has an eye to the silver, as if she hadhad the polishing thereof; whilst he, in his funny way, callsher "auntie," to the amusement of all the Miss Menzies andthe Farquharson girlies, who, by the way, crowd in, simplybecause they are neighbours; for Aunt Alison declaresthey are not even outside connections, nor in any wayrelated to the family.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Subsisting chiefly on the provisions supplied bya fleet, which, sailing along the coast, accompaniedhis movements, the English general approachedthe capital, where Lesley had settled his headquarters. The right wing of the Scottish armyrested upon the high grounds at the rise of themountain called Arthur's Seat, and the left wingwas posted at Leith ; while the high bank, formerly called Leith Walk, made a part of his lines,which, defended by a numerous artillery, completely protected the metropolis. Cromwell skirmishedwith the Scottish advanced posts near to Restalrig,but his cuirassiers were so warmly encounteredthat they gained no advantage, and their generalwas obliged to withdraw to Musselburgh.

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: South-westward,Arthur's Seat, its dark brow touched with sunlight throughthe mist; Salisbury Crags nestling sullenly below; and inthe valley at the feet of both, the low, irregular pointed-towered Holyrood House—ehief goal, after all, of most ofthe pilgrimages paid to the whilouie capital of the Stuarts. Northward and eastward, running at the foot of the HillLeith Walk, a broad handsome street leading down sometwo miles to Leith itself, the old seaport of the Capital, andperhaps known to more than remember it through its histor-ical reminiscences as the landing-place of royal personsvisiting Scotland, from one of those old songs which willkeep running through the head when more practical thingsshould be remembered : °

title: The Comfort of Saturdays
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: She thought  of Eddie's circumstances. Cat had said something once about where he lived; he was still with his parents somewhere, she believed, somewhere down  off Leith Walk. Eddie's parents were elderly, she now remembered; he had been something of an afterthought.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 21
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: "Whatails ye, George?" was the uniform question; and every time it was put itwent to his heart, for it showed more and more, as he thought, hissick-like appearance, which seemed to escape the eyes of no one. The menassisted him more assiduously than they had ever done before; and havinggot everything ready, he proceeded up Leith Walk. The toll-man noticedalso his dejected appearance, and the same question was put by him.

title: Ghost Moon
author: Butlin, Ron
snippet: Fred Astaire top hat, bow-tie and tails like he's stepped out of a black-and-white film, he'll pause for a moment as if taking a good look round – searching, probably, for the next Ginger Rogers. Scouting out the talent, it used to be called at Fairley's Ballroom and the other dance halls on Leith Walk and along Princes Street. Sweeping his hat from his head, he gives the entire room a boulevardier bow of such well-prac-tised elegance that you can imagine the intake of breath on all sides.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 02
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: I wasput ashore in the boat, and hastened up to the Black Bull Inn, in orderto secure a seat in the mail for Glasgow, which was to start in a fewminutes. As I came up Leith Walk, my feelings became of a mixed nature. I thought of Widow Niel and the murder, as I looked over at the Calton;then my mind reverted to my bride.

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: Thewhole interview irritated me also, I must confess, whichwas the more to be regretted as I had promised to conducta meeting at eight o'clock in the Canongate for my friendGeordie Stewart, who was ill. However, in order to shakeoff my ruffled feelings, and to acquire a better frame ofmind for the exercises of the evening, I started out forArthur's Seat, and lay on my back for an hour on SalisburyCrags, alone with Nature and Nature's Creator; and whenI walked down the Canongate a little before sunset, mymind was calm once more, and I had completely forgottenthat the city contained such a quarter as Leith Walk, orsuch a stiffneckit old gentleman as my Uncle Arnold. Itwas only at the very peroration of my discourse that I wasstartled by the snapping of a certain well-known snuffboxlid, and a subsequent stifled sneeze; and you must admit,

title: Travels in the United States of America, in the years 1806& 1807, and 1809, 1810, & 1811;
author: Melish, John
snippet: Leith is considered as the port of Edinburgh, and is connected with it by a very broad avenue, nearly two miles long, called Leith Walk. The whole population of Edinburgh and Leith was, in 1801, 82,560.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: The night was chill and starry ; all the way eastward  the trees of the different gardens rustled and looked black. Up the stone gully of Leith Walk, when they came to cross it, the breeze made a rush and set the flames of the street-lamps quavering; and when at last they had mounted to the Royal Terrace, where Captain Mackenzie lived, a great salt freshness came in their faces from the sea. These phases of the walk remained written on John's memory, each emphasized by the touch of that light hand on his arm ; and behind all these aspects of the nocturnal city he saw, in his mind's eye, a picture of the lighted drawing-room at home where he had sat talking with Flora ; and his father from the other end, had looked on with a kind and ironical  smile.

title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 23
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: It was a sad time too, but so gay and sohopeful, and we had such sport with all our low spirits and all ourdistresses, that it looks like a kind of lamplit fairyland behind me. Ofor ten Edinburgh minutes--sixpence between us, and the ever-gloriousLothian Road, or dear mysterious Leith Walk! But here, a sheer hulk,lies poor Tom Bowling; here in this strange place, whose verystrangeness would have been heaven to him then; and aspires, yes, C. B.,with tears, after the past. See what comes of being left alone.

title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 25
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: This is a map of theenvirons of Edinburgh _circa_ 1750. It must contain Hope Park, Hunter'sBog, Calton Hill, the Mouter Hill, Lang Dykes, Nor' Loch, West Kirk,Village of Dean, pass down the water to Stockbridge, Silver Mills, thetwo mill lakes there, with a wood on the south side of the south onewhich I saw marked on a plan in the British Museum, Broughton, Picardy,Leith Walk, Leith, Pilrig, Lochend, Figgate Whins. And I would like apiece in a corner, giving for the same period Figgate Whins,Musselburgh, Inveresk, Prestonpans, battlefield of Gladsmuir, Cockenzie,Gullane--which I spell Gillane--Fidra, Dirleton, North Berwick Law,Whitekirk, Tantallon Castle and Castleton, Scougal and Auldhame, theBass, the Glenteithy rocks, Satan's Bush, Wildfire rocks, and, ifpossible, the May.

title: Robert Louis Stevenson
author: Black, Margaret Moyes
snippet: Very amusing features of the letters that Mrs Thomas Stevenson sent homewere the funny illustrations of daily life enclosed in them, and whichwere drawn by a clever pencil in the household. Like the old plays inthe Leith Walk shop the youthful Louis once so frequently visited, theywere _A Penny Plain and Twopence Coloured_. Sometimes they were mereoutlines of domestic processions, sometimes they were gay with paint inshades of brown and green and blue.

title: Ghost Moon
author: Butlin, Ron
snippet: before sweeping left down into Leith Street, past  Fairley's Ballroom where the squaddies and sailors still battled out the war with each other, not that she'd ever be going there again. Then past the Playhouse cinema where the organist on his platform rose up through the floor to play during the interval, past treelined Elm Row and into Leith Walk proper. Yes, this was her city.

title: Travels in the United States of America, in the years 1806& 1807, and 1809, 1810, & 1811;
author: Melish, John
snippet: i to the ladies, they are elegant to a proverb. Those who have ever been on " Leith Walk in the gloaming," can bear witness to their " angelic forms," their " rosy complexions,"  and their " witching smiles." But as I might be accused of partiality for my fair countrywomen, were I to speak my mind on this subject, I shall take my leave of the Edinburgh ladies, by addressing the younger part of them in the words of Robert Burns :

title: My first visit to Europe:
author: Dickinson, Andrew
snippet: None of their American descendants but me, that I know of, ever crossed the dark waters to the Old World. Leith Walk is a fine broad avenue of stores and dwellings connecting the two places. No vestige remains of the pier at which the Queen of Scots landed, on her arrival at Leith from France, in 1561 . The wild waves of the German Ocean were lashing the beach, and the bare legs of women and children.

title: The reminiscences of Thomas Dibdin,
author: Dibdin, Thomas
snippet: The whimsical, good-natured irritability of this gentleman, who was my sole companion, rendered our journey irresistibly comic to me : he found fault with every thing, and paid the waiters liberally ; abused the Land of Cakes more than ever the great lexicographer had done ; and damned the crows for visiting such a soil, when they had good strong black wings to carry them any where else ; and yet he could not give me one single substantial reason  for his discontent. We met with the greatest  attention and civility wherever we stopped ; got a good broiled fowl for dinner on the road ; and were finally set down in excellent quarters, at the Bull's Head, at the top of Leith Walk. As I was more than in time for my engagement at BamfF, where my friends at present were, — I determined, instead of proceeding by diligence or chaise, to go to Aberdeen by sea, and lay out the difference of expense in a few days' residence in Edinburgh, in order to see all I could get access to in that classically interesting capital.

title: David Balfour, etc.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: My way down the causeway of Leith Walk wouldhave been more pleasant to me but for this encounter. The old rampart ran among fields, the like of them

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]
author: Pitt, Sarah.
snippet: Something went wrong with the kitchen rangeabout this season, and Mrs. Sage went to confer witha certain ironsmith in Leith Walk on the subject. She took Nell with her for company, but Nell soontired of listening to the discussion about flues andback-draughts, and sauntered back to the doorway.

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: He and his young Scottish bride spent a day together inthe large house in Leith Walk, where they met all the restof 'the connection' ; and it amused them both to see howvery little change their new relationship wrought in theelderly couple. Aunt Alison's first care was still that thefurniture and silver might reflect credit on her guardianship ;whilst her new husband still persisted in styling her ' Awntie.'

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: On Thursday morning Ivy took leave of Uncle PeterArnold and all the household in Leith Walk. The oldhousekeeper wiped her eyes, and declared it was just the' pittin' oot o' the sunlicht;' and Uncle Arnold was in a

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: ' Aunt Ailie will be sorry to have missed you, observedMary Gray. 'But I'll tell her you were here, and that willplease her ; and she will, of course, be at Leith Walk onSaturday, as usual, for the " family tea," and you will makeher acquaintance then."

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: ' Uncle Arnold waited till the room was well-nigh empty,and then, rushing forward in his dear old abrupt way, graspedmy hand with one of his, and, laying the other on myshoulder, said kindly, " Aweel, lad, considerin' all things, andyour bringin' up, I suppose ye must hae yer heid ! Anyway,it'll no be said there were twa stiffneckit folk in the connexion. Frae what I've gaithered here this evenin', I maunadmit ye'll do us credit after a', sae ye maun jist gang awahame wi' me to Leith Walk !" And, sure enough, there wereSandie and the horses waiting outside the little meetinghouse, and I had to drive home here to this house, which isto be my home now, until, as Uncle Arnold says, I " have apu'pit, an' a kirk, an' a hoose o' my ain." Aunt Alison doesnot look quite pleased with the arrangement, and I know allshe wanted was that her own small revenues should continuethe same as before.

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: She offered me no seat, and refrained from all questions,and I soon perceived that, to be tolerated, I must exertmyself to say something interesting. Rather unwillingly,therefore, I disclosed the rupture that had taken placebetween my kinsman and myself, and the ignominiousmanner in which 1 had been banished from the mansion inLeith Walk. She had been totally ignorant of the wholeoccurrence, and now listened to the account of it withevident satisfaction.

title: David Balfour, etc.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Eachtime it occurred to me, the ingenious foulness of thatcalumny he had proposed to nail upon my characterstartled me afresh. The case of the man upon thegibbet by Leith Walk appeared scarce distinguishablefrom that I was now to consider as my own. To rob achild of so little more than nothing was certainly apaltry enterprise for two grown men ; but my own tale,as it was to be represented in a court by Symon Fraser,appeared a fair second in every possible point of view ofsordidness and cowardice.

title: The reminiscences of Thomas Dibdin,
author: Dibdin, Thomas
snippet: wrapped up in an envelope of sail-cloth ; and impelled by fatigue and my late involuntary exertions, I fell into a sound sleep, which lasted till about five in the morning, when I think I never more poignantly felt the visitation of hunger. Delighted at this certain symptom of health, how did I bless the prevoijance of my kind friend Lee, of the Bull's Head, at the top of Leith Walk, for filling my basket so abundantly!  and how did I anathematise the dishonest and unfeeling voracity of those on board, who had devoured every atom of my chickens, my ham, my manchets, and my " wee puckle o' saut ;" and not only drank every drop of my farintosh, but feloniously, and without the fear of any thing before their eyes, conveyed away my bottle !

title: Hanleys; or, Wheels within wheels
author: Caumont, Mary.
snippet: And now Isee that, busy as I am preparing for my examination, I haveactually written a longer letter than usual, and certainlymuch longer than I had intended when I began. Give mybest love to the whole household at Edgewood, and tellmamma not to be uneasy about my wardrobe, as it is inexcellent condition at present, thanks to the deft fingers ofMiss Mary Grey, who, before my things left Cheviot Row,darned my stockings and repaired my shirts so neatly, thatthe old housekeeper here at Leith Walk put on her spectacles to examine them, and asked, " What for a wee fairybody had been over my duds wi' needle and threed? Noyer ain mither, Maisther Joe, eh?"

title: Story of a Stolen Heir. A novel
author: Bertram, James Glass.
snippet: and gentlemen of the jury, there are manyinstances in the criminal records of variouscountries of people being put to death whowere yet quite innocent of the crimes ofwhich they were convicted. A Uttle morethan a century ago (in November, 1721),WilUam Shaw, an upholsterer, was hangedat the place of execution in Leith Walk forthe murder of Catherine, his daughter. Theman was as innocent of the crime as I am;but from some unfortunate concurring circumstances, he was fixed upon as the criminal and found gudty.

title: Art Rambles in the Highlands and Islands of Scotland ... With ... sketches, etc
author: Reid, John T.
snippet: rendered poor and bald, and will soon have to give place. George Streethas fewer buildings that have altered their frontage; but Leith Walk has quitechanged its character, and is now the link that binds in one strong bond theseaport town to its queenly city. Within my own memory a large part of itwas without houses, and there were long rows of quaint one-storied dwellingsoccupied by small shopkeepers, bird-sellers, showmen, menders of shoes, andmakers of sweetmeats.

title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: Tickler. Only a coach rattling down Leith Walk. Let us be seated.

title: Robert Louis Stevenson
author: Black, Margaret Moyes
snippet: He was before very long a book-buyer as well as a book-lover, and he hasfor ever immortalised, in the charming pages of _A Penny Plain andTwopence Coloured_, that old bookshop (late J. L. Smith) at the cornerof Leith Walk, where eager boys without coppers were but coldlyreceived, but whence the fortunate capitalist could emerge, after havingspent his Saturday pocket-money, the proud possessor of plays positivelybristling with pirates and highwaymen. With these treasures he fled homein the gathering dusk, while 'Leerie-Light-the-Lamps' was kindling hischeery beacons along the streets, and, with pleasant terrors, devouredthe weird productions, finally adding to their weirdness by the garishcontents of a child's paint-box.
